Brad from Denver is spot-on. Anyone who has had the misfortune of having to even drive through Lancaster or Palmdale knows that they are towns positioned in the middle of nowhere (from the viewpoint of most Southern Californians) that have traditionally been poor and white, with a moderate representation of Latinos. Summary: Their city planners unwisely overbuilt. The housing bubble burst. They now have high numbers of vacancies that are being filled by subsidized tenants. End result: two formerly poor, white communities are now poor and mix-raced.

Neither city was desirable before the housing boom & bust, but now the demographics have changed, and the people in charge still reflect the old guard who are not thrilled about the changes to their cities.

I know a lot of problems often accompany Section 8 tenants, but believe me when I say that Lancaster & Palmdale were never Shangri-La in the first place. The mayors ought to be glad that anyone at all is filling the vacancies out there in the desert, adding to their local sales tax and other revenues, and keeping their towns from looking like modern-day ghost towns.

I always found televisions in hospitals such an unwelcome presence--the loud volume, the canned laughter, the overly bright colors, the predictable content and schedule juxtaposed against the very spontaneous and uncertain drama of being sick in real life.  I was amazed to realize some men turn on the TV in the labor room when their wives are having babies.  TV seems so terribly unreal and intrusive in that setting.  Yet I remember visiting my mother in the hospital when she was getting chemotherapy -- it was the night that Nixon's funeral was  broadcast.  I don't think we had ever talked about Watergate when it was happening-- I was only 11.  But that night my mother surprised me by saying she had always felt bad for him because he hadn't done anything worse than many other politicans--he just got caught.  It seemed like such a sad end of the messy 70s, the last years of my childhood.  I remember Bob Dole kept repeating the phrase "How American" in a way that seemed so robotic and heavy-handed, as if he could redeem some sliver of Nixon's legacy if he said it enough, and clearly, he couldn't.  It was such a sad and unusual thing to watch-- I don't think either one of us would have watched it normally, but there we were in a hospital room, my mother was very tired, and that's what was on TV.  And then, completely unexpectedly, she had a stroke that night and died, so my last moments with her were watching Nixon's funeral on TV.  Such a strange and unpredictable thing.

Against my better instincts, I gave several CFL brands a try during the past year. Couldn't stand them. The models I chose were touted as "warm and natural," but it was still like living inside a 24-hour gas station convenience store. Minus the scratch-off lottery tickets.

As one reader has mentioned, CFLs' lifespans are greatly shortened if you frequently turn them on and off. Let's face it, just about every light in a typical home is switched on and off multiple times each day. So as I and my wallet discovered, these very expensive bulbs become even more expensive since they last only a fraction of the time their manufacturers claim.

And yes (those same manufacturers assure us), each bulb contains only a small amount of mercury. Supposedly, this is "safe" provided each bulb is treated as toxic waste and disposed of carefully and properly.

But anyone with half a brain knows that 99% of all users will simply toss their burned out CFLs bulbs into the trash. And a decade or two hence? When tens of millions of CFLs end up smashed in landfills, and all their collective mercury seeps down into the water table and ends up in our rivers and streams?

Sorry, CFLs are no bargain. I've gone back to incandescents.

actually the point of a point system is to create another level of abstraction to purchases and thus do an end run around the part of our brain that doesn't want to spend money. Our primate brains are very familiar with the concept of spending, or giving up something, and are averse to doing so. By creating levels of abstraction, spending doesn't "feel bad" anymore. By making the numbers weird, like giving things prime number values that are not easily divided, yet another block is put into place to keep us from controlling ourselves when making impulse purchases.

You can see this type of psychological warfare in use in many online games that have in game purchases. They get the spending money part of the game as far as possible from the buying things part so that it's much easier and seemingly less painful to do so. The same trick is used in many fairs where tickets for rides and food are purchased separately from the transactions.

Bottom line is, it works.

Three things to note:

1) For most lighting, there's an inverse relationship between the warmth of the "best" lamp and the amount of light. For a brightly lit office, kitchen, or bathroom, the best lighting is cool white or daylight (4100K-6500K). For a dimly lit dining room, the best lighting is very warm 2200K-2700K.

2) Most LED lamps have a very efficient blue-violet LED source covered by a phosphor cap that converts some of the blue to other colors. The cheapest LED lamps have an orange phosphor. More expensive lamps have better phosphors to give a more balanced spectrum. The choice of phosphors is the biggest cause for poor color rendering. Companies are developing quantum-dot phosphors which will soon (mid 2012) make really nice phosphors. Some premium LED lamps you can buy today have RGB sources inside which give perfect color rendering.

3) A better way for government to promote LED technology would be to push it on businesses first. In particular, it ought to be pushed on restaurants. It's hard to find a restaurant today that doesn't use arrays of wasteful incandescent lamps. These are ideal places to retrofit with high-quality CFL and LED lamps. Restaurants are usually air-conditioned, have several identical fixtures, are lit 12 hours a day, and are high-profile locations. They are perfect places to showcase LED lighting.

This story makes me cringe. It's saddening that housing advocates choose to sue cities, instead of addressing the serious problems within the Section 8 program.
.
Section 8 has no requirements for habitability, beyond simply meeting local building codes. As a result, slum lords often view the vouchers as free money. They don't screen tenants the way they should, so not only is the housing substandard, it's crime ridden.
.
In fact, in 1986 the Federal Government saw these problems and created Low Income Housing Tax Credits (LIHTC). LIHTC landlords get tax breaks in return for setting aside a percentage of their units for low-income tenants. They are required to accept Section 8 vouchers, but they also have to meet very strict requirements for habitability and safety. LIHTC housing tends to be good quality, and relatively crime free; in marked contrast to housing that just gets Section 8 vouchers.
.
If housing advocates really wanted quality housing for the poor, they'd do something about the inherent problems in the Section 8 program. They wouldn't sue cities.
